messages.message:
@Ted @Chetan using these definitions and the example you gave Ted, ontop of what Chetan wrote:
Precision: Of the values IB extracted, what percentage should have been extracted?
Recall: Of the values that IB should have extracted, what percentage was extracted?
Accuracy: What percentage of the time does IB extract nothing when nothing should be extracted and extract the correct value when something should be extracted?

Precision: If I see a creature in the woods, how often do I guess correctly its a Moose.
Recall: If I see Moose in the woods how often do I guess it correctly to be a Moose.
Accuracy: How often do I see a creature in the woods and guess if its a Moose or Not.

Is that an accurate analogy?
No
P: when I say it’s a moose, how often am I correct.
R: of all mooses, what % did I identify
A: at high level, you might say this is “an aggregate score that tolls P and R together”
*rolls
Fantastic thank you, will still need to translate A, into moose terminology but thanks!
Np!
Another way to think about what it means is that precision is basically “can I trust you when you’re confident?”
Like, if I come running back to the office and say “guys I had the best idea!! Found the best customer!!”
Can you trust me?
And recall is basically how prolific a hunter you are.
This is extremely helpful especially because I didn't have a clear understanding but now do, and I now can tell customers this.
Like if there are 100 good ideas/customers out there. Do I come back having gotten one of them? All of them?
So recall is less about trust and more about coverage
For example: you can have 0 precision and 100% recall by just always saying yes
And you can have 0 percent recall and 100 percent precision by always saying no
So there is an inherent trade off between the two at the theoretical level
And often times, when you fine tune a system, it involves proactively deciding which is more important at the margins
Because at the margin you can never optimize for both
Since they are in tension with each other
Which means if you’re in a convo with customers and they start asking about why is the precision this but the recall thAt etc etc
This is really great stuff, thank you!
You can comfortably say things like “within reason, we can help you tune based on which is more important for a use case”
